UI_visible_response: The Beijing LGBT Center closed due to "force majeure," which is described as a euphemism for state coercion, indicating that the closure was a result of government pressure1. The center officially announced its closure citing "unpreventable circumstances" and "forces beyond our control," further emphasizing the impact of external pressures, likely from the government, on its operations4. This event is part of a broader pattern of increased restrictions and crackdowns on LGBTQ activism and community spaces in China2.
traffic_visible_response: The Beijing LGBT Center closed due to "force majeure," which is described as a euphemism for state coercion, indicating that the closure was a result of government pressure [[1]]. The center officially announced its closure citing "unpreventable circumstances" and "forces beyond our control," further emphasizing the impact of external pressures, likely from the government, on its operations [[4]]. This event is part of a broader pattern of increased restrictions and crackdowns on LGBTQ activism and community spaces in China [[2]].
